Orthographic Variants: atl tepetl, yn atl yn tepetl, altepetli, altebet, altebetl
Principal English Translation: town, pueblo; ethnic state; sovereign sociopolitical unit; community; literally, contains the elements atl, water, and tepetl, hill, natural features that might once have been appealing for choosing where to settle, e.g. the site of a natural mountain spring
no, not; or, a term that negates

paper (originally made from fig bark, from the ficus tree) or the tree itself; a letter; a document; not knowing "paper" meant not knowing "writing" (i.e. not knowing how to write), not being literate; San Pablito Pahuatlan, in the Sierra Norte de Puebla, is a town where the amatl paper-making tradition has been conserved
water; a body of water, such as a lake, river, or ocean; floods, flooding (part of a metaphor for war, atl tlachinolli); liquid beverage, even chocolate; urine; fontanelle; also, a calendrical marker
aunt
to leave to, abandon, relinquish something or someone (applicative form of cahua)
to enter, to go inside someplace; could also take on the meaning of invasion associated, for instance, with the Spanish entrada
to leave something for a relative (nic.); to leave for oneself something from a group of things being distributed to others (nicno.)
to receive something (as in a testament); to accept; to admit something; to host someone; to become tender or bud
to placate; to rest; to put out fire, snuff (candle); to cool off; for the wind to stop; to become calm, become quiet, extinguished

Orthographic Variants: çohuātl, cioa, cioatl, ciuatl, zouatl, suatl, çiva, civatl, zohuatl, zihuatzintli, zihuatl
Principal English Translation:
woman; wife (when possessed); also, the name of a person, attested in sixteenth-century Morelos; also, the word for uterus and possibly hymen

See also zohuatl, for additional attestations.
to buy; to buy something; to hire; originally had a reciprocal sense to it
to sleep
for something to break, bust open, snap, break in two, such as a rope, thread, etc.; to be broken off
a child, boy or girl
to give health, strength; strengthen; to confirm; to enforce; or, for a human or an animal to become mature or aged
to await, expect, look for
and
to go; to go along (well or badly), mainly seen in the 3rd person
something new or recent
to surround something; to surround one's enemies; or, to be the first to complain about others; to go in procession; to go many times around something
yesterday
by itself (himself, herself), apart, alone, aside, separate, in private
in jail; tied up; someone or something bound
nighttime, each night, or all night, night after night; also, "the night, the wind" was another way of referring to the deity of the near and far; darkness, shadow

to leave, abandon, relinquish, deliver, let (nic.)
to remain, survive, be left (mainly in third person) (nino.)

for there to be a break in the lineage (metaphorical)
irregular combining form of itta; to see
a month; moon; crescent; see also our entry for metztli meaning the leg of an animal or a person (and see Molina)
son-in-law
mother-in-law, mother of one's wife
soul (this word is usually seen possessed in Nahuatl)
to live; to dwell; to be; to go around, to go along; to walk; often seen at the end of a verb, with the effect of to go about doing that act
to measure something
order, to put in order; to put in a row
to go down, descend, sink; to lower, diminish; to digest food; also, to descend the musical scale
is located (especially referring to chinampas), which is akin to the definition of "to be stretched out;" also, to fill, fill up; to become full, to swell; or, to be fed up
something made, a creation; a creature, a child, offspring; or, an accomplishment

clay, mud; part of a formula in testaments for referring to the body (reflecting Christian influences)

https://aztecglyphs.wired-humanities.org/content/zoquitl-33r
grasses, hay, straw, weeds, forage, fodder, bulrushes

a Spanish dry measure, one-twelfth of a fanega, typically used to explain how much land can be planted in this quantify of seed; almoh is the contemporary variation from Eastern Huastecan Nahuatl (IDIEZ)
tomorrow; the next day; in the future (an expression of time); see also our entry -moztlayoc
literally, "human horned owls," but meaning sorcerer, witch; devil, demon; native person practicing pre-Columbian religion in colonial times; a possessed person

a reed or cane; also, a calendrical marker (used as both a day name and a year name), and a personal name; these reeds were made into darts and arrows; in hieroglyphs the acatl takes on a number of different visual forms
to pour something into a container, to cause something to fill up; to put something into a container or the like, to fill it up; when reflexive, to bathe in a temazcalli, a steam bath
an orphan, someone or something poor, humble, worthy of compassion and aid
a day; a saint's day; a festival day, a holiday (a special day with religious significance)
to be watery, wet; to fill up with water, to flood
water snake
a rattle, a gourd rattle (Sahagún)
something liquid, such as wine or honey; or, someone who has been corrected and scolded
turtle; also, a person's name (attested as male)
to eat; to bite; can also be seen in association with living off the land (eating and drinking from the land) in the Historia Tolteca-Chichimeca; and, the verb can be used to speak of an eclipse
to bathe oneself or another person; or to sacrifice and kill enslaved people as offerings to divinities, or to offer ornaments to the temple or church
book(s) or codex/codices; see also the entry amoxtli meaning water plant

famine; or, a glutton

liquid; something melted, runny; something rare; something as transparent as glass

ice, icicle; frost (Sahagún)
